importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date when Nicolas Sarkozy is expected to begin his five-year prison sentence in La Santé prison, marking a historic moment as the first former French president in living memory to be imprisoned.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The five-year prison sentence begins on October 20, 2025, and will conclude in October 2026, defining the duration of Sarkozy’s incarceration.

keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy is the first former French president to be imprisoned in living memory.
He was convicted of criminal conspiracy related to financing his 2007 election campaign with Libyan funds.
He will begin serving his sentence at La Santé prison in Paris, which has housed high-profile inmates such as Captain Alfred Dreyfus and Carlos the Jackal.
Sarkozy maintains his innocence and has denied wrongdoing, but the court ruled that he must serve time immediately due to the seriousness of the public order disruption.
He will not be allowed to file an appeal until he is inside prison, and any request for release will be processed within two months by the appeals court.
He will be housed in a 9-square-meter cell, possibly in the 'vulnerable' or VIP section, with limited personal items and no access to outside communication.
Sarkozy will bring three books (including 'The Count of Monte Cristo' and a biography of Jesus Christ) and 10 family photos, as allowed under prison regulations.
A former businessman-turned-author, Pierre Botton, and longtime friend Patrick Balkany, have described the likely conditions and psychological impact of incarceration on former high-profile inmates.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicolas Sarkozy, former president of France, has been convicted of criminal conspiracy for using Libyan funds to finance his 2007 election campaign, and will begin serving a five-year prison sentence on October 20, 2025, at La Santé prison in Paris. As the first former French president to be imprisoned in living memory, the case marks a significant moment in French political history. Despite maintaining his innocence, the court ruled that he must serve time immediately due to the severity of the public order disruption. He will be housed in a small 9-square-meter cell, possibly in a 'vulnerable' or VIP section, with limited personal belongings. Former inmates, including Pierre Botton and Patrick Balkany, describe the psychological and physical shock of incarceration, emphasizing that even former presidents are subject to the same conditions as ordinary prisoners. Sarkozy has expressed resolve to maintain dignity and fight through the legal process, bringing books and family photos to the prison. The case raises broader questions about accountability, political power, and the treatment of former leaders in the justice system.
title: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy Begins 5-Year Prison Sentence for Campaign Finance Conspiracy
